column1: In making a gelatine emulsion with zinc it must be decidedly acid or it fogs. I prefer nitric acid for the purpose. I also found that some samples of the bromide behaved in a very peculiar way. All went on well until it came to the washing
column2: when the bromide of silver washed out slowly
column3: rendering the washing water slightly milky; this continued until the whole of the bromide of silver was discharged from the gelatine
column4: and the latter rendered perfectly transparent as in the first instance. I remember a gentleman mentioning at one of the meetings of the South London Photographic Society that he was troubled in the same way as I was at that time. I think if a few experiments were made in this direction with the zinc salt and worked out
column5: it would be a great advantage.
